title: Terrorism in Europe classified
text:
The attack by a heavily armed gunman on a synagogue in the German city of Halle in which two people died has again highlighted the grave threat posed by some right-wing extremists.

German Interior Minister Horst Seehofer labelled the incident — on Yom Kippur, the holiest day of the year in Judaism — as an "anti-Semitic attack." But although terrorism arrests in Europe linked to right-wing extremism were four times higher last year compared with 2015 (rising from 11 to 44) the number of successful attacks remains low.

In 2018, there was just one successful attack, according to Europol's Terrorism Situation and Trend Report. In February, a man went on a shooting spree in Macerata, a city in central Italy. He wounded six people he believed were Africans and was charged with multiple counts of attempted murder. He had previously run unsuccessfully in local elections for the anti-migrant League party, according to the Europol report.

In the same year, there were 84 attacks classed as ethno-nationalist or separatist; 24 jihadist attacks; and 19 by left-wing extremists. Here's how terrorism in Europe breaks down:
